DOC.brief_summary: The main objective of the study was to evaluate ginger efficacy as an adjuvant to ketoprofen for the treatment of headache and other symptoms related with migraine attacks.
DOC.brief_title: Ginger Capsules for the Acute Treatment of Migraine Attacks
DOC.detailed_description: Patients with the diagnosis of migraine according to the IHS criteria were enrolled in the study during a migraine attack. Patients received two 200 mg capsules of dry ginger extract (5% active ingredient) or two capsules of placebo (cellulose) in addition to an intravenous dose of ketoprofen (100 mg) to treat the migraine attack.
DOC.criteria: Migraine diagnosis for at least one year; One to six migraine attacks per month. Patients with headaches not characterized as migraine; Pregnant or lactating women; Fertile and sexually active women who do not use contraception; Abuse of painkillers, alcohol or drugs; People with hypersensitivity to ginger; People with other neurological diseases; People in use of anticoagulant drugs; People who have started the disease after 50 years old.
